title: Psalms Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 6.

questions.question: Who is the author of Psalms Chapter 6 according to the text?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:1 states it is a Psalm of David.

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask the LORD not to do in his anger?
questions.correctAnswer: Rebuke him
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:1 says, 'O LORD, rebuke me not in thine anger.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 6:2, why does the psalmist ask for mercy?
questions.correctAnswer: Because he is weak
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:2 says, 'Have mercy upon me, O LORD; for I am weak.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'O LORD, heal me; for my ______ are vexed.'
questions.correctAnswer: bones
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:2 states, 'O LORD, heal me; for my bones are vexed.'

questions.question: What is the psalmist's soul described as in Psalms 6:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Sore vexed
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:3 says, 'My soul is also sore vexed.'

questions.question: How does the psalmist describe his nights in Psalms 6:6?
questions.correctAnswer: Making his bed swim
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:6 states, 'all the night make I my bed to swim; I water my couch with my tears.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 6:5 says that in death there is remembrance of God.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:5 says, 'For in death there is no remembrance of thee.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 6:7, why does the psalmist's eye wax old?
questions.correctAnswer: Because of all his enemies
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:7 says, 'Mine eye is consumed because of grief; it waxeth old because of all mine enemies.'

questions.question: Who does the psalmist ask to depart from him in Psalms 6:8?
questions.correctAnswer: All ye workers of iniquity
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:8 states, 'Depart from me, all ye workers of iniquity.'

questions.question: True or False: The LORD has heard the voice of the psalmist's weeping according to Psalms 6:8.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:8 says, 'for the LORD hath heard the voice of my weeping.'

questions.question: What will the LORD do with the psalmist's prayer according to Psalms 6:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Receive it
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:9 says, 'The LORD will receive my prayer.'

questions.question: What is the psalmist's request for his enemies in Psalms 6:10?
questions.correctAnswer: Let them be ashamed
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:10 says, 'Let all mine enemies be ashamed.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 6:4 asks the LORD to save the psalmist for His mercies' sake.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:4 states, 'oh save me for thy mercies' sake.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 6:6, what does the psalmist water his couch with?
questions.correctAnswer: Tears
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:6 says, 'I water my couch with my tears.'

questions.question: Complete the verse from Psalms 6:3: 'My soul is also sore ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: vexed
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:3 states, 'My soul is also sore vexed.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is overwhelmed and feels weak in spirit. Based on Psalms 6, what biblical truth would you share about God's care in such times?
options: God shows mercy and heals those who are weak
God ignores the weak and focuses on the strong
Human strength is enough without God's help
Suffering is a sign of God's rejection
questions.correctAnswer: God shows mercy and heals those who are weak
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:2 teaches that God has mercy and healing power for those who are weak, emphasizing His compassion and care.

questions.question: How does Psalms 6 instruct us to respond when we feel deeply troubled and our soul is sore vexed?
options: Cry out to the Lord and ask how long the suffering will last
Ignore the feelings and pretend all is well
Give up hope and stop praying
questions.correctAnswer: Cry out to the Lord and ask how long the suffering will last
questions.explanation: In Psalms 6:3, the psalmist openly expresses sorrow and asks God 'how long?', showing that honest prayer in distress is biblical.

questions.question: When facing trials, how does Psalms 6 encourage believers to trust in God's mercy?
options: By asking God to return and deliver the soul for His mercies' sake
By relying only on personal strength
By refusing to ask for help
By delaying prayer until troubles pass
questions.correctAnswer: By asking God to return and deliver the soul for His mercies' sake
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:4 highlights trusting God's mercy by requesting deliverance, encouraging believers to depend on His compassion.

questions.question: What does Psalms 6 teach about the finality of death in relation to praising God?
options: In death, there is no remembrance or thanksgiving to God
The dead continue to praise God forever
Death increases our ability to praise God
Death has no impact on worship
questions.correctAnswer: In death, there is no remembrance or thanksgiving to God
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:5 states that in death, remembrance and praise of God cease, reminding believers to seek God in life.

questions.question: How can a believer maintain a spirit of prayer during times of deep sorrow as shown in Psalms 6?
options: By continually crying out to God and pouring out tears in prayer
questions.correctAnswer: By continually crying out to God and pouring out tears in prayer
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:6 illustrates the psalmist making his bed swim with tears, showing that persistent prayer and honesty with God in sorrow is encouraged.

questions.question: What lesson about dealing with enemies can be learned from Psalms 6?
options: God hears the cries of the righteous and will bring shame upon the workers of iniquity
We should seek revenge on enemies ourselves
Ignore the presence of enemies completely
Enemies have the power to overcome God's people permanently
questions.correctAnswer: God hears the cries of the righteous and will bring shame upon the workers of iniquity
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:8-10 teaches that God hears the weeping of the righteous and will cause enemies to be ashamed, encouraging trust in God's justice.

questions.question: How does Psalms 6 guide a believer to respond when feeling abandoned or in distress?
options: Call out to the Lord for mercy and healing
questions.correctAnswer: Call out to the Lord for mercy and healing
questions.explanation: The psalmist in Psalms 6:1-2 implores God for mercy and healing, showing the importance of turning to God in distress.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 6, God is indifferent to the prayers of those who suffer.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:9 clearly states that the Lord has heard the supplication and will receive the prayer, showing God’s attentive care.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 6 encourages believers to be patient and trust that God will answer their prayers.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The psalmist’s repeated requests and confidence in God’s mercy (Psalms 6:3-4, 6:9) teach patience and trust in God’s timing.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Let all mine enemies be ______ and sore vexed.'
questions.correctAnswer: ashamed
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:10 calls for enemies to be ashamed and sore vexed, reflecting the psalmist's trust in God's justice.

questions.question: How does the psalmist describe his emotional state during his prayers in Psalms 6?
options: Weary with groaning and tears flowing through the night
questions.correctAnswer: Weary with groaning and tears flowing through the night
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:6 describes the psalmist as weary with groaning and wetting his bed with tears, showing deep emotional distress in prayer.

questions.question: What does Psalms 6 reveal about the importance of honesty before God in prayer?
options: The psalmist openly expresses grief and asks God how long the suffering will continue
Prayer should always be cheerful and positive
One should hide feelings of sorrow from God
questions.correctAnswer: The psalmist openly expresses grief and asks God how long the suffering will continue
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:3 shows that being honest about pain and asking God questions is part of sincere prayer.

questions.question: Based on Psalms 6, what role does grief play in a believer’s spiritual life?
options: It is a valid expression before God that leads to seeking His mercy
It should be hidden to maintain a strong image
It indicates a lack of faith
It should be ignored and suppressed
questions.correctAnswer: It is a valid expression before God that leads to seeking His mercy
questions.explanation: The psalmist’s grief (Psalms 6:7) is openly expressed and leads him to call on God’s mercy, indicating grief’s place in spiritual honesty.

questions.question: How does Psalms 6 instruct believers about God’s response to sincere prayer?
options: God hears and receives the prayers of the righteous
God ignores prayers during hard times
Prayers are only answered after long delays
God only listens to perfect people
questions.correctAnswer: God hears and receives the prayers of the righteous
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:9 assures that the Lord hears supplications and receives prayers, affirming God’s attentiveness.

questions.question: What practical Christian virtue is demonstrated by the psalmist in Psalms 6 through his repeated prayers and pleas?
options: Perseverance in prayer and humility before God
questions.correctAnswer: Perseverance in prayer and humility before God
questions.explanation: The psalmist’s continual pleas in Psalms 6:1-4 and emotional honesty show perseverance and humility in seeking God’s help.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 6.

questions.question: What is the primary emotional state expressed by David in Psalms 6:6, and how is it physically manifested?
options: Weary with groaning, expressed by wetting his bed with tears
questions.correctAnswer: Weary with groaning, expressed by wetting his bed with tears
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:6 states, 'I am weary with my groaning; all the night make I my bed to swim; I water my couch with my tears,' indicating the emotional state of weariness and sorrow is physically manifested by tears.

questions.question: In Psalms 6:1, what does the phrase 'neither chasten me in thy hot displeasure' reflect about ancient Near Eastern views of divine anger?
options: Divine anger is mild and forgiving
Divine anger is intense and purifying
Divine anger is irrelevant to human affairs
questions.correctAnswer: Divine anger is intense and purifying
questions.explanation: The phrase in Psalms 6:1 reflects a cultural understanding that God's anger is severe and can act as a form of discipline or purification, typical in ancient Near Eastern theology where divine wrath is not taken lightly.

questions.question: Which theme in Psalms 6:4 is echoed in the New Testament plea for salvation in Luke 18:13?
options: Mercy as a basis for salvation
questions.correctAnswer: Mercy as a basis for salvation
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:4 says, 'oh save me for thy mercies' sake,' which parallels Luke 18:13 where the tax collector asks for mercy rather than justice, emphasizing mercy as foundational for salvation.

questions.question: In Psalms 6:5, what theological assertion is made about the state of the dead and remembrance of God?
options: There is no remembrance of God in death
The dead intercede for the living
questions.correctAnswer: There is no remembrance of God in death
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:5 states, 'For in death there is no remembrance of thee,' which asserts that the dead are no longer able to praise or remember God, reflecting ancient Hebrew views of Sheol as a place of silence.

questions.question: How does the structure of Psalms 6 reflect a chiastic pattern in its emotional progression?
options: Starts with joy, moves to lament, ends with joy
Begins with plea for mercy, moves to despair, returns to confidence
questions.correctAnswer: Begins with plea for mercy, moves to despair, returns to confidence
questions.explanation: The psalm begins with a plea (vv.1-2), moves through deep despair and grief (vv.3-7), and concludes with confident hope and enemy defeat (vv.8-10), forming a chiastic structure emphasizing restoration.

questions.question: What Hebrew word translated as 'rebuke' in Psalms 6:1 carries the connotation of divine correction or discipline?
questions.correctAnswer: Yasar
questions.explanation: 'Yasar' is the Hebrew root often translated as 'rebuke' or 'chasten,' implying divine correction, as seen in Psalms 6:1's plea not to be rebuked in anger.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the typological significance of David’s plea for healing in Psalms 6:2 in the broader biblical narrative?
options: It prefigures Old Testament laws on health
It is unrelated to New Testament themes
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows Christ's healing ministry
questions.explanation: David’s plea 'O LORD, heal me' in Psalms 6:2 typologically points forward to the healing works of Jesus in the New Testament, showing a pattern of God's restorative power.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 6:8, David's enemies are told to 'Depart from me' because the LORD has ignored his weeping.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:8 states, 'Depart from me, all ye workers of iniquity; for the LORD hath heard the voice of my weeping,' indicating the LORD has heard, not ignored, David's weeping.

questions.question: How does the lament in Psalms 6:3 'My soul is also sore vexed: but thou, O LORD, how long?' reflect the motif of divine silence found in Habakkuk 1:2?
options: Both express impatience with divine delay
Both deny the existence of God
questions.correctAnswer: Both express impatience with divine delay
questions.explanation: The verse expresses a plea asking the duration of suffering, paralleling Habakkuk 1:2 where the prophet questions how long God will allow injustice, highlighting impatience with divine silence.

questions.question: What literary device is predominantly used in Psalms 6:7 with the phrase 'Mine eye is consumed because of grief; it waxeth old because of all mine enemies'?
questions.correctAnswer: Hyperbole
questions.explanation: The verse uses hyperbole to emphasize extreme sorrow and weariness by saying the eye is consumed and waxeth old, a common poetic device in Hebrew lament.

questions.question: Which cultural practice from the ancient Near East is reflected in David's reference to 'watering my couch with my tears' in Psalms 6:6?
questions.correctAnswer: Weeping as ritual mourning
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, weeping was part of ritual mourning practices, and David's metaphor of wetting his bed with tears reflects this cultural expression of deep sorrow.

questions.question: In Psalms 6:9, the LORD's reception of prayer indicates what aspect of divine-human relationship in biblical theology?
questions.correctAnswer: God actively listens and responds
questions.explanation: The verse shows that God hears and receives prayer, highlighting an intimate and responsive relationship between God and the believer.

questions.question: Which other biblical book contains a similar lament structure as Psalms 6, including pleas for mercy and declarations of enemy shame?
questions.correctAnswer: Lamentations
questions.explanation: Lamentations contains similar poetic laments with pleas for mercy and expressions of enemy defeat, paralleling Psalms 6's structure and themes.

questions.question: What is the significance of the psalm being 'to the chief Musician on Neginoth upon Sheminith' as stated in Psalms 6:1?
options: It indicates a musical instruction for performance
It refers to a prophetic message
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates a musical instruction for performance
questions.explanation: 'Neginoth' and 'Sheminith' are musical terms indicating the psalm was intended for a specific style or instrument, showing the integration of music in worship in ancient Israel.

questions.question: How does the plea for healing in Psalms 6:2 relate to the concept of the 'suffering servant' in Isaiah 53?
options: Both describe physical and spiritual suffering
Both reject the idea of suffering
questions.correctAnswer: Both describe physical and spiritual suffering
questions.explanation: David’s plea in Psalms 6:2 for healing of vexed bones parallels the suffering servant’s pain and affliction in Isaiah 53, highlighting themes of bodily and soul suffering.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Psalms 6:1, what does David ask the LORD not to do in His anger?
questions.correctAnswer: Rebuke him
questions.explanation: David requests, 'O LORD, rebuke me not in thine anger' (Psalms 6:1). This highlights God's justice and mercy. Similarly, in Exodus 34:6-7, God's mercy is emphasized alongside His justice; Psalm 38:1 also speaks of God's anger, and Jonah 4:2 contrasts God's mercy with His wrath.

questions.question: According to Psalms 6:2, why does David ask for mercy and healing?
options: Because he is weak and his bones are vexed
Because he is rich and healthy
Because he is joyful and strong
Because he is proud and arrogant
questions.correctAnswer: Because he is weak and his bones are vexed
questions.explanation: David's plea for mercy and healing is grounded in his weakness and bodily distress (Psalms 6:2). This echoes the biblical theme of human frailty as in 2 Corinthians 12:9, Isaiah 40:29, and Psalm 73:26, where God's strength is made perfect in human weakness.

questions.question: What does David ask repeatedly in Psalms 6:3, reflecting his soul's condition?
questions.correctAnswer: How long, O LORD?
questions.explanation: David's repeated question 'how long?' (Psalms 6:3) expresses the tension of suffering and waiting for God's deliverance, which aligns with Habakkuk 1:2, Romans 8:23-25, and Lamentations 3:25-26 about patient hope in God's timing.

questions.question: In Psalms 6:4, for what reason does David ask the LORD to save and deliver his soul?
options: For the sake of the temple
For the peace of the nation
questions.correctAnswer: For thy mercies' sake
questions.explanation: David appeals to God's mercy as the basis for salvation (Psalms 6:4). This concept is consistent with Exodus 33:19, Ephesians 2:4-5, Titus 3:5, and Lamentations 3:22-23, emphasizing salvation as an act of divine mercy, not human merit.

questions.question: What theological truth is expressed in Psalms 6:5 regarding death?
options: There is no remembrance of God in death
The soul lives forever in death
questions.correctAnswer: There is no remembrance of God in death
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:5 states, 'For in death there is no remembrance of thee,' highlighting death's finality and the absence of praise in Sheol. This aligns with Ecclesiastes 9:5, Psalm 146:4, John 11:25-26 (where Christ contrasts death with resurrection), and Revelation 20:14 which speaks of death's ultimate defeat.

questions.question: How does David describe his emotional and physical distress in Psalms 6:6?
options: Weary with groaning and watering his bed with tears
Joyful and singing praises all night
questions.correctAnswer: Weary with groaning and watering his bed with tears
questions.explanation: David describes his deep anguish: 'I am weary with my groaning; all the night make I my bed to swim; I water my couch with my tears' (Psalms 6:6). This reflects human suffering and lament similar to Jeremiah 31:16, 2 Corinthians 1:8-9, Romans 8:18, and Psalm 42:3.

questions.question: What is the cause of David's eyes being consumed and waxen old according to Psalms 6:7?
options: Because of grief and all his enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Because of grief and all his enemies
questions.explanation: David's eyes suffer 'because of grief' and 'all mine enemies' (Psalms 6:7), revealing the burden of persecution and sorrow. This is parallel to Job 16:16, Psalm 31:9, Luke 18:7, and 1 Peter 4:12-13 regarding suffering and enemy opposition.

questions.question: Who does David command to depart from him in Psalms 6:8?
questions.correctAnswer: All ye workers of iniquity
questions.explanation: David commands 'depart from me, all ye workers of iniquity' (Psalms 6:8), indicating separation from the wicked. This theme of separating from sin is found in 2 Corinthians 6:17, Proverbs 4:14-15, Psalm 1:1, and James 4:7.

questions.question: According to Psalms 6:9, what has the LORD done in response to David's supplication?
options: He hath heard and will receive his prayer
questions.correctAnswer: He hath heard and will receive his prayer
questions.explanation: David affirms God's attentive hearing and acceptance of prayer (Psalms 6:9). This reflects God's responsiveness in 1 John 5:14, Jeremiah 33:3, Matthew 7:7-8, and Luke 18:1-8.

questions.question: What is the fate David wishes upon his enemies in Psalms 6:10?
options: Let them be ashamed and sore vexed
Let them prosper and be joyful
questions.correctAnswer: Let them be ashamed and sore vexed
questions.explanation: David prays for the shame and distress of his enemies (Psalms 6:10). This petition aligns with Psalm 35:4, Romans 12:19, Psalm 69:26, and 1 Samuel 17:47 concerning divine justice toward adversaries.

questions.question: What is the significance of David calling this Psalm to the 'chief Musician on Neginoth upon Sheminith' (Psalms 6:1)?
options: It indicates a solemn, meditative musical setting for deep lament
It means the Psalm should be sung joyfully at festivals
It is a command to ignore the Psalm
It instructs to perform it silently
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates a solemn, meditative musical setting for deep lament
questions.explanation: The musical directions in Psalms 6:1 suggest a serious, perhaps eighth-stringed instrument accompaniment (Sheminith) for a lament, reflecting the Psalm's penitential tone. Similar musical instructions appear in Psalms 4:1 and 12:1, indicating the importance of worship context in expressing theology.

questions.question: How does Psalms 6:4 reflect God’s attribute of mercy in relation to salvation?
options: David asks for salvation based on God's mercies, showing God’s compassion
David claims salvation is earned by works
David demands salvation as a right
questions.correctAnswer: David asks for salvation based on God's mercies, showing God’s compassion
questions.explanation: David’s plea 'save me for thy mercies’ sake' (Psalms 6:4) highlights God's compassionate mercy as foundational to salvation, consistent with Exodus 34:6, Psalm 103:8, Ephesians 2:4-5, and Lamentations 3:22-23 which emphasize God’s enduring mercy and grace.

questions.question: What eschatological implication can be drawn from Psalms 6:5’s statement about death and remembrance of God?
options: It underscores the urgency of praising God while alive since death silences worship
It declares death as a gateway to worship
It states that death increases remembrance of God
questions.correctAnswer: It underscores the urgency of praising God while alive since death silences worship
questions.explanation: Psalms 6:5 teaches that 'in death there is no remembrance of thee,' implying worship is for the living, urging believers to honor God now. This is consistent with Ecclesiastes 9:5, Hebrews 9:27, Luke 16:26, and Revelation 14:13 which emphasize the finality of death and the importance of life's faithfulness.

questions.question: In theological terms, what does David’s repeated groaning and weeping in Psalms 6:6 reveal about human suffering?
options: It illustrates the biblical reality of lament as an expression of trust and dependence on God
It shows that suffering is always a punishment without hope
It indicates that God is indifferent to human pain
It suggests that suffering is to be hidden
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates the biblical reality of lament as an expression of trust and dependence on God
questions.explanation: David's open lament in Psalms 6:6 reflects a biblical pattern where lament is used to express distress while still trusting God, as seen in Job 3, Lamentations 3, 2 Corinthians 1:3-7, and Hebrews 4:15-16, affirming God's presence in suffering.

questions.question: What does the departure of 'workers of iniquity' in Psalms 6:8 signify in the context of God's justice and holiness?
options: It signifies separation of the wicked from the righteous in the presence of God
It means the wicked are welcomed into God's presence
It suggests that sin is unimportant
It implies that all people are workers of iniquity
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies separation of the wicked from the righteous in the presence of God
questions.explanation: David’s command for the wicked to depart (Psalms 6:8) highlights God's holiness and justice requiring separation from sin, consistent with Isaiah 59:2, 2 Thessalonians 1:6-9, Revelation 21:27, and 1 Corinthians 6:9-11.
